--- "Kent Beck" <kentb@e...> wrote:
> We don't plan to make that possible. I would like to know
> in what circumstances non-public test classes and methods
> would be valuable.

In a test class with a static suite method to generate a number of 
tests from data, I have an inner private static TestCase class with 
test methods that I'll want to reuse in a number of different data-
driven test scenarios.  I find that I must copy and paste a fair 
amount of TestSuite code into my child class of TestSuite to 
accomplish this.  ...and to do TestCase constructors and/or methods 
with non-standard argument lists.

Q: Why do I want the inner class not to be public?
A: So that Eclipse, Ant and other IDEs (and tools) don't automatically 
pick it up and try to run all its methods.  (...which, when run 
outside of my intended context, always fail.)
